review.title: Number game
review.abstract: CLARIN (Common Language Resources and Technology Infrastructure) is regarded as one of the most important European research infrastructures, offering and promoting a wide array of useful services for (digital) research in linguistics and humanities. However, the assessment of the users for its core technical development has been highly limited, therefore, it is unclear if the community is thoroughly aware of the status-quo of the growing infrastructure. In addition, CLARIN does not seem to be fully materialised marketing and business plans and strategies despite its strong technical assets. This article analyses the web traffic of the Virtual Language Observatory, one of the main web applications of CLARIN and a symbol of pan-European re-search cooperation, to evaluate the users and performance of the service in a transparent and scientific way. It is envisaged that the paper can raise awareness of the pressing issues on objective and transparent operation of the infrastructure though Open Evaluation, and the synergy between marketing and technical development. It also investigates the "science of web analytics" in an attempt to document the research process for the purpose of reusability and reproducibility, thus to find universal lessons for the use of a web analytics, rather than to merely produce a statistical report of a particular website which loses its value outside its context.

sections.heading: 2.1 User centric approach for marketing and development
sections.text: The European Commission describes in the Principles for Access to Research Infrastructures: "Research infrastructures should have a policy that defines how they regulate, grant and support (potential) users from science, business, industry and public services" (European Commission and Directorate-General for Research and Innovation 2016). Nevertheless, it is estimated that CLARIN has strong support from the linguistic community in Europe and has successfully implemented a number of projects in recent years demonstrating the value of academic and research infrastructure in its own right. However, despite the emphasis on users in the principles, user evaluation in CLARIN is rather minimal. In other words, infrastructure development is largely focused on planning and doing in the sense of PDCA5 and the review and action are highly limited. Recent publication (Eckart et al. 2015) reports on the user behaviour of VLO, one of the flagship services of CLARIN, but it does not provide any prior literature on the subject.

sections.heading: 4 Playing a fair game? –methodological issues of web analytics
sections.text: This section discusses the procedural and methodological aspects of web analysis in general. It is intended to focus on the "science of our experience" of analyses, hypotheses and interpretations of web traffic, which remains relatively untouched in studies of web analytics.The section is divided into two parts: the first part attempts to open and analyze the black box of web analysis, the second part discusses the techniques and tips used for analysis to document the research experience and share it with other analysts of the future.

sections.heading: 4.1 Opening the black box

sections.heading: 4.2 Tips for data analysis
sections.text: Although some may need a little training, Piwik is generally an intuitive and user-friendly tool, capable of recording and generating many different statistics on website usage. At the same time, it also seems true that many analysts use only the most basic (and preset) functionality without bothering to consider various aspects of statistics, and therefore do not achieve their full potential. As a result, the data is sometimes neither adequately interpreted nor presented to stakeholders, which would also be a consequence of the current research environment in which time may not be invested enough for marketing and business analysis. In this section, some tips for web analytics are documented in our analysis in Section 3. The concept of open evaluation that this paper proposes is a small attempt to draw attention to this issue and break the barrier of access to the accumulated experience of web analysis. In addition, a broad category of open science and innovation also falls within the framework of this idea, in order to encourage knowledge transfer and exchange (although Google's use of the Analytics Documentation is similar to the Documentation of Democracy).

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Segmentation
sections.text: Standard statistics are a good way to know the general trend, but they should not be interpreted without careful consideration of smaller segments. As repeatedly stated in Sections 3.4 and 3.5, user profiles and behaviors are different in different user groups. Thanks to Piwik's faceting feature, we can easily specify specific groups based on a variety of criteria and regular expressions, including IP address (Figure 27). As seen in Section 4.1, we are even able to track the behavior of a unique user. sections.heading: 4.3 Myth or truth? –intuition, interpretation, and induction
sections.text: In Section 3, the author deliberately avoided providing the last and only interpretation of the data. Rather, he subtly packs a series of steps that point to the process of data analysis and interpretation. It is true that we have common sense or intuitive interpretation when we first look at a data set, based on previous experience, so we have a mutual understanding of the "vague probability," in our case, of web traffic. The problem is that the evidence of such interpretation is often lacking and the process of induction is not documented. Thus, we mentioned Wynne (2015b) in the introduction. To address this problem, one can find many traces of "analysis / research documentation." sections.heading: 5.2 Challenges for CLARIN’s infinity and beyond –A little Kaizen
sections.text: This article presented a minimum amount of user analysis that attempts to address the problems of the user-oriented development method with respect to web traffic. It is not possible to use readily available statistics to increase the marketing value of the VLO. Thus, the usefulness and potential of Pihttwik have been successfully demonstrated. Furthermore, the author intentionally documented the process of data analysis and interpretation in the name of research reusability and reproducibility. Although such a documentation aspect of web analysis has made this paper rather eloquent, it is hoped that other researchers would benefit from it in the future. The current problem of the technical and business development of CLARIN is the absence of a simple PDCA methodology and the documentation of visions and business strategies. As far as the author recognizes, the check is preliminary conducted through internal testing and feedback, focusing on bug fixing and self-contained improvements.
